pros: Great, supportive leadership. Allow you autonomy but you can be confident they’ll support you. They value good work and you will feel appreciated. The staff are caring, dedicated, and a great team to work with.
cons: Like many public agencies, funding is tight. Parking is a problem.

pros: Teaching hospital. Altruism. Ok pay. Lots of specialities so there are places to move if desired.
cons: Lack of support. Different hierarchies mean problems with clinic managers are unaddressed since not in the same chain of command. Lots of travelers. Few pay increases over many years. Lack of flexibility for work/life balance. Care too much about Press Ganey and not enough about outcomes.

pros: Great way to use your talents to give back, aging facility that is always in need of repair.
cons: Senior leaders undermine management authority

pros: great coworkers cafeteria has vegan options from local restaurants
cons: A policy was changed between the time I was hired and when I started yet no one thought to let me know. No one would address the situation and renegotiate my contract. HR is completely useless. Emails with 4 HR individuals and CC'd Kate Becker herself on 3 of the emails and nothing. My own HR representative never even responded as he 'isn't the one to help' so he just didn't respond. I used to think problems were kept departmentally but it's a system-wide company problem which to me is even worse. It's been four months since I quit and I can't even get an exit interview. They didn't hold up their end of the bargain but are demanding me to keep mine. Weasels. Would not recommend unless you appreciate disrespect.

pros: Benefits Flexibility Good work environment
cons: I dont have any cons at this time

review_title: The providers are amazing, the hospital is not
job_title: Psychology Postdoctoral Fellow in Albuquerque, NM
pros: All of the actual providers that I work with (including doctors, nurses, NPs, surgeons, psychologists, social workers, etc) are amazing. They are thoughtful, kind, collaborative, appreciative, smart
cons: I've really struggled with HR and admin for basic things, like getting the moving reimbursement that I was promised in my interview. There are very few paid holidays. All new employees have to wait five months before taking a paid vacation day, which seems incredibly tone deaf and inappropriate in the modern work era

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant (CMA) in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Flexible schedule Good experience and learning opportunity
cons: lower pay than other hospitals

pros: Staff on inpatient oncology unit work really well together & help each other out.
cons: Nurses at UNMH are undervalued & underpaid. Ratios are unsafe (oncology unit/progressive care) with 5-6 patients, several receiving chemo. There isn’t enough time to give our patients what they truly need & deserve. The hospital doesn’t care, keeps on accepting more & more patients & giving unsafe assignments, all while not increasing pay of experienced nurses. New grads are making more than nurses with 5+ years experience.

review_title: Good for getting the experience you will need

cons: Not a lot of room for growth.

pros: Great people to work with

pros: Good company to work in NM.

job_title: Systems Analyst II in Albuquerque, NM
pros:
-The best part of working here is the people you work with (for the most part).
-Tuition reimbursement (though you must pay tuition in the beginning of the semester and then UNMH will reimburse after the courses are passed).
cons:
-Infrequent and low raises are a joke. No cost of living adjustments, and on average, only a 1% raise (if you get one at all). 
-Employee parking is 1 mile away and must take a shuttle to get to the hospital, which can take 15+ minutes. 
-New employees start out at higher pay than tenured staff. 
-Salary is non-negotiable during hiring or promotions
-Educations/Certifications aren't taken into account when determining pay. Solely based on years of experience, even if only minimally relevant. 
-Low staffing due to the hospital not being willing to take care of employees

pros: Nice people, co-workers are helpful.
cons: Awful staffing ratios, management will run you like a dog. Night shift? Good luck eating.

job_title: IT Project Consultant in Albuquerque, NM
pros: UNM's clinicians really, really care about the mission. They're often given the leeway and focus to do what they need to do to take care of their patients. It was definitely the best part of the job. Clinicians at UNM truly care.
cons: Leadership clearly lacks a backbone to effectively support our clinicians. They're constantly lacking in vision or basic understanding of the scope of work or how we add value. Constantly changing priorities and a lack of follow-through on basic questions of IT software functionality are telling. There's simply no awareness of industry standards or quality IT management. Petty politics reign supreme.

review_title: When you join this institution, proceed with the thought "This is just a training period!"
pros: If you are starting out and need to obtain experience, there is an excess supply of patients here for you to practice your craft upon. The quality of training is highly variable. You will leave here in one year or three years but you will leave. Your ultimate goal in joining this hospital is to better yourself for the next position where you can negotiate better salary, benefits, etc.
cons: Since this hospital serves everyone (an admirable virtue), you will experience a small percentage of your patient population that are drug seekers, malingerers, and terribly unappreciative of the care they receive. However, if you keep your eyes set upon that next job, you'll do fine here. Do not ever come to UNMH with the hopes of a long a prosperous career. You will tremendously disappointed.

review_title: Good start in medical, bad for long term growth

job_title: Nutrition Care Aide in Albuquerque, NM

pros: good learning opportunities; good colleagues
cons: high turnover rate; poor management

pros: Only Level 1 Trauma Center, fast paced, teaching hospital
cons: High crime rate in area of hospital

review_title: Overall a great place to work!
pros: Computerized self scheduling gives great flexibility and allows you work around your family life and schedule.  Teaching hospital is a wonderful environment to learn in.  Staff is helpful and supportive.  Diverse patient population.  Evidence based practice used widely throughout the hospital.  Efforts are made to stay up to date on best practices, policies, and trends to promote best outcomes for patients and safest envrionment for workers.
cons: A little too micromanaged. Inconsistent pay raises, and no recognition or incentive for seniority or longevity with the company.  New grads being hired in at always increasing competitve pay, but no compensation or change in pay scale for those already working there.  Rumor is, you have to quit and get rehired for your experience to be compensated for and that just isn't the right way to do things.

pros: You have health benefits.  And as long as you are not a supervisor, you are union protected.
cons: Pay is horrible.  Management treats their employees like robots.  Graveyard shift workers are always left out of special events during the day.  Also have the most work load and the least amount of staff to complete all tasks.  If overtime happens, you get in trouble.  And there is definitely favortism when it comes to promoting from within.  People who have been there for well over a decade and know more about the department than most get passed over for a job that they do when the supervisor is not there.  Someone who has been there for only a year gets the job because he's buddy buddy with his boss.

job_title: Outpatient Behavioral Health Position in Albuquerque, NM
pros:
I have worked here for over 10 years. I have a decent paycheck and benefits.  We are an outpatient clinic, so we are pretty much left alone by upper management, which is nice :)
I work with a great group of co-workers and have an excellent supervisor and clinical manager who actually listen to the workers, and really do care for the patients.  I am always treated fairly and with respect!  Very grateful to work here!
cons: The only thing I would say that is kind of negative is that Outpatient Behavioral Health services techs do not get any recognition for the hard work we provide to clients.  There are some awesome workers that would appreciate some kind of recognition.  All we ever hear about are the inpatient unit workers at UPC or the main hospital getting awards and employee of the month.  A little bit of recognition would really boost moral.

pros: Always busy, plenty of work to do, immediate supervisors tend to be attentive, make a difference in patients' lives. Little chance of layoffs, job security is fairly high. I would recommend to a friend WITH reservations-- would make the cons clear before recommending UNMH.
cons: Low paying jobs, extremely rare raises, and no room for advancement AT ALL. Immediate supervisors are unwilling to take a stand against higher levels of management, stressful work environment, staffing is a constant issue, often times you must take on several work loads due to scheduling mishaps, mixed messages about OT, some patients are horrendous, chance of getting attacked my insane people (not a joke-- very serious).

review_title: Great place to learn about nutrition
pros: If you are looking to pursue a career in dietetics the RDs are more than willing to help you grow and teach you until you apply or get accepted to a dietetic internship.  You get to interact with patients, review charts and practice assessing patients based on risk.  Good benefits
cons: If you are looking to advance in an area other than nutrition I feel like it has been hard.  Management and staffing isn't what it needs to be and it has been this way for quite some time.

pros: Decent benefits/discounts to theater and sporting events.  Flexibility and working from home !!
cons: Management lied about transition to VR and then proceeded to outsource to Nuance.  Pay per line pre-Nuance 10 cents; post 3 cents.  Bottom line is money-  quite a savings for the hospital but final product looks unprofessional, mistakes galore (unedited left as is).  VR is a sign of the times but hospital could've had the current employees carry on as editors but they chose to outsource with East Indians doing the majority of the work.  So much for loyalty and 15 years of dedication.

pros: My coworkers are some of the most amazing and hard working nurses around. We get really good training. There is room for advancement if you want it.
cons: I do not feel adequately protected from infectious diseases. It is a teaching hospital so in July question everything the new doctors put in. Sometimes they fire people for dumb reasons. They don’t really have a float pool so if someone calls in sick it’s the end of the world. Supply issues are sometimes a problem. We run out of random things. It is a hospital so changes take a long time if they happen at all. A startup might fix an obvious problem within the week, here it might take months or years.

pros: Lots of continuing ed and shared governance opportunities. Close-knit units. You get to care for the sickest of the sick, which is very educational and challenging.
cons: Sometimes hostile environment. Lack of rapport between long-time nurses and new nurses. Management constantly in flux. Lots of churn in nurse staffing on some units. Onerous continuing ed requirements

review_title: Management terrible & nurses who are not a team
pros: Decent pay, tuition reimbursement, lots of options for jobs, some wonderful providers
cons: Management is out of control, allows some nurses to bully and fight in front of patients, play favorites, charge nurse sat at computer never helping the team to succeed, they want you to be a doormat in order to make management happy, nurses crying in hallway due to mistreatment, poor or no training in some units, some providers walk around like everyone else is scum, literally had one look at a wall to avoid eye contact with me and my smile

review_title: Solid Training, Good Pay and Benefits
pros: Diverse patient population, interesting pathology, good pay given local cost of living (now that we have union representation), excellent benefits.
cons: Support staff can be lazy or indifferent (the Southwestern attitude of "there's always manana!"), management is not always in touch with employee issues, clinical workload is significant and does not always allow for time to do research.

pros: great coworkers; good teamwork; dedicated to the health and welfare of the patients; worked in two different departments there; learned many things and software programs. Still the best hospital system in the city. Only Level 1 Trauma Center for the entire state of New Mexico!
cons: sometimes too top heavy in administration; pay freezes in bad economy; still has bad reputation with the public; some of the units still show wear and tear from their age.

pros: Excellent teamwork, clinical career ladder, Shared governance model used, supportive, accessible management,
cons: Minimal cost of living raises, little incentive for retention

review_title: Steady under-employment; no raises; no future advancement
pros: Steady employment; job security; low stress workplace. Job satisfaction is largely based on supervisor. I have three supervisors: 2 good, one "out-to-lunch"!
cons: No chance for advancement in my department; No merit or any raises in more than 3 years; when advancing salary is restricted by "15% rule".

pros: I enjoyed working with the staff and learned a clam and different kind of nursing after doing  a very stressful job for many years.
cons: The nursing administration are bullies and when you report them they retaliate. I felt discriminate because I am native American Indian.   A hospital that has Native American Indian around each corner they sure don't know how to work with us or respect our culture.

pros: My direct supervisor is a wonderful person.  There is a lot of interpersonal support.
cons: Too much drama.  The hoops you have to jump through to make any effective change make you feel very defeated.  The message received is "we've always done it this way and you are not going to change anything for the better."

pros: Excellent support in a teaching hospital environment with a lot of opportunity for continuing education! You will work with a very skilled multidisciplinary team and have the opportunity to attend many lectures that are free.
cons: The pay is not competitive compared to other positions in the community and the health insurance is very expensive, especially for a family.

review_title: Worked in the NICU, level III.
pros: Team work of the nurses is good.  Good pay with great differentials.  Busy times do have overtime incentives.   Assignments are usually fair and manageable
cons: Poor management in NICU, dishonest, no positive involvement.  Will place babies in non-spaces when busy leading to infection control issues

review_title: Old school organization, which is better for employee rights, but does not revere college educated staff.
pros: Excellent benefit package and paid employer health insurance (single coverage).
cons: Horrible parking situation and most office supervisors have NO degree whatsover.

pros: Great benefits and pay! There are some truly hardworking employees and wonderful providers.
cons: Poor management, unqualified supervisors, negativity and criticism provided by those who are unfamiliar with  the job.

pros: The retirement is a 5% contribution.
cons: The health insurance will not cover most things. You end up pain out of pocket for overpriced medical care. * think $900 flu test, when you knew you just had a sinus infection.

review_title: You do not have a voice
pros: good benefits for their employees
cons: Very political.  If you are a favorite you are good. If not... your life is hell working here.  You are not allowed to have a voice and speak up.  We need an employee advocate for those not covered by the Union.

job_title: Advanced Practice Nurse in Albuquerque, NM
pros: We are the best in the state! All of the top specialists are here. We are the Mayo Clinic of New Mexico
cons: The only real down side is parking. The employee parking is off campus: you have to take a shuttle

pros: The University of New Mexico Hospitals offered good working conditions and benefits.
cons: Upper management was often less interested in patient care than in the department's fiscal standing.

pros: Giving back to the community and learning more about disease processes.

 Increased insurance rates by 30%.

cons: Though we pay nothing out of pocket for personal insurance from our paychecks, I shell out a lot of money if I want to see a doctor or for basic healthcare.
